case_name: Sri Vedaraneeswararswamy Devasthanam v. Dominion of India and Province of Madras

facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No.371 of 1956 from the Judgment and decree dated August 28, 1953, of the Madras High Court in A.S. No. 262 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.371 of 1956. Appeal from the Judgment and decree dated August 28, 1953, of the Madras High Court in A.S. No. 262 of 1949.

facts.text: Suit filed by the Managing Trustee of the appellant Sri Vedaraneeswararswamy Devasthanam against respondents 1 and 2 the Dominion of India and the Province of Madras respectively.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been brought with a certificate issued by the Madras High Court and it arises out of a suit filed by the Managing Trustee of the appellant Sri Vedaraneeswararswamy Devasthanam against respondents 1 and 2 the Dominion of India and the Province of Madras respectively.

facts.text: Appellant claimed declaration that properties in suit belong to the appellant and direction against respondent 1 to put appellant in possession.

anchor.surface_text: In this suit the appellant claimed a declaration that the properties in suit belong to the appellant and asked for a direction against respondent 1 to put the appellant in possession of the same.

facts.text: Suit properties admeasure about 2,400 acres situated in the village of Agastiyampalli granted in inam absolutely to the appellant by the Tanjore Rajas several centuries ago.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant the suit properties which admeasure about 2,400 acres are situated in the village of Agastiyampalli and the said village was granted in inam absolutely to the appellant by the Tanjore Rajas several centuries ago.

facts.text: From the time of the said grant the appellant was in exclusive possession and enjoyment of the said properties.

anchor.surface_text: From the time of the said grant the appellant was in exclusive possession and enjoyment of the said properties, and its trustees and managers used to look after them and collect their profits for the use and benefit of the appellant.

facts.text: In 1806 an agreement was reached between the East India Company and the appellant under which the Company took possession of the appellant's properties in suit and promised to pay 1848 Pagodas annually.

anchor.surface_text: In 1806 an agreement was reached between the East India Company and the appellant, under which the Company took possession of the appellants properties in suit and in return promised to pay a sum of 1848 Pagodas annually.

facts.text: Out of 1848 Pagodas, 1200 Pagodas represented the rent of the property.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this amount 1200 Pagodas represented the rent of the property. Pursuant to this agreement the Company took possession of the said property and was paying the agreed rent until 1858.

facts.text: Company paid agreed rent until 1858, then respondent 2 succeeded and paid until 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this agreement the Company took possession of the said property and was paying the agreed rent until 1858. In that year respondent 2 which succeeded the Company entered into possession of the property on the same terms and was making the annual payment of the said sum until 1937.

facts.text: Thereafter respondent 1 took over the salt revenue administration and properties came into its possession and has been paying the agreed amount from year to year.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter respondent 1 took over the salt revenue administration and as such the properties came into its possession. Respondent 1 has been paying the appellant the agreed amount from year to year.

facts.text: Appellant's case: true legal relationship was lessor and lessee, annual or yearly lease continued from year to year.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that the true legal relationship between the parties was that of a lessor and lessee and that the lease itself was number of a permanent character but was one in the nature of annual or yearly lease which was continued from year to year.

facts.text: Respondent 1 disputed: held properties under annual lease; instead compensation fixed once for all based on average income previous ten years, under Regulation 1 of 1805, Rs. 4,200/- corresponding to 1848 Pagodas.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1 disputed this claim., It denied that it held the properties under an annual or yearly lease. Its case was that when the suit lands, were taken over by the Company compensation was fixed once for all, the average income of the appellant from the manufacture of salt carried on by the appellant during the previous ten years having been taken as the basis for the purpose of calculating the said compensation.

facts.text: Learned Subordinate Judge of Mayuram tried the case, rejected claim, held permanent arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: This claim has been rejected by the learned Subordinate Judge of Mayuram who tried the case and an appeal preferred by the appellant against the trial courts decision has likewise failed.

facts.text: Madras High Court agreed with trial court, held permanent arrangement/lease, barred by limitation Art. 134 B of Limitation Act, confirmed decree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in substance agreed with the conclusions of the trial court. It considered the whole of the documentary evidence and came to the conclusion that the trial judge was right in holding that the documentary evidence showed that the arrangement by which the Company took possession of the appellants properties was a permanent arrangement and that if it was held to be a lease it must be regarded as a permanent lease.

facts.text: Ex. A.1 is copy of order passed by Mr. Wallace on December 31, 1806, addressed to manager of temple.

anchor.surface_text: The principal document is Ex. A. 1. It purports to be a copy of the order passed by Mr. Wallace on December 31, 1806. It is addressed to the manager of the temple and it reads thus As the Government have taken charge of the pagoda salt pans and Sea Customs of Thopputhurai, belonging to the above temple, the sum of 1848 Pagodas shall be given to the temple annually in cash from the treasury being calculated on the average amount of 10 years revenue besides which every possible assistance will be given to the temple.

facts.text: No duration specified in Ex A1, prima facie Government took charge permanently, pay annually.

anchor.surface_text: It would be noticed that there is no duration specified in the document, and prima facie it reads as if the Government had taken charge of the salt pans and Sea Customs permanently promising in return to pay to the temple the amount specified annually from year to year.

facts.text: Correspondence: letter July 17, 1806 to Board of Revenue explaining acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: On July 17, 1806, a letter was addressed to the President and Members of the Board of Revenue in which the idea of acquiring this property was fully explained.

facts.text: Compensation calculated on average 10 years revenue from salt manufacture and port duties: total 1848 Pagodas.

anchor.surface_text: In computing the compensation which may be paid to the temple the accounts of the pagoda were examined. ,It was found that the pagoda enjoyed revenue from the duties levied at ports at Thopputhurai and Kodikarai. Ten years account showed that the average annual income in that behalf was. 283 Pagodas. To this amount was added the amount of magama or charitable and litigious fees and the total worked out at an average of 532 Pagodas. From this was deducted 46 Pagodas which was the average of charges and expenses incurred in collecting the port duties. Thus the net annual average revenue was 486 Pagodas. Then an account was made of the income received by the temple from salt manufacture in the salt pans and it was ascertained that an average income in that behalf would be Star Pagodas 1362. That is how the whole annual income was found to be 1848 Pagodas.

facts.text: Property intended to be acquired permanently for manufacturing salt.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the perusal of this document leaves no doubt that the property was intended to be acquired permanently for the purpose of manufacturing salt.

facts.text: Secretary to Government letter October 28, 1806 recommended payment not exceeding 1848 Pagodas per annum.

anchor.surface_text: In the letter written by the Secretary to the Government on October 28, 1806, it was recommended that a payment should be made from the public treasury of a compensation for the loss which the pagoda had sustained by the introduction of salt monopoly in the Province of Tanjore not exceeding Star Pagodas 1848 per annum.

facts.text: Board accepted on November 17, 1806.

anchor.surface_text: The proposal thus made by the Government was accepted by the Board and its decision was communicated by the letter of November 17, 1806.

facts.text: From 1806 to 1941, appellant allowed Company and successors quiet enjoyment on annual compensation.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that from 1806 when the Company took possession of the property until 1941 the appellant has allowed the Company and its successors to be in quiet enjoyment of the property on receipt of an annual compensation paid from year to year.

facts.text: In 1941 factory officer wrote to trustee enquiring about revenue villages and compensation.

anchor.surface_text: In 1941 the factory officer wrote to the trustee of the appellant to let him know the name or the names of the revenue villages to which the area covered by the. salt factory was originally attached prior to the acquisition, and he enquired whether any compensation amount had been paid to the temple for the said acquisition.

facts.text: Appellant replied April 8, 1941 alleging property leased to Government for Rs 350 monthly or Rs 4200 annually.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after receiving this letter the appellant wrote to the factory officer on April 8, 1941 alleging that the property had been leased out to Government for the manufacture of salt for a monthly lease of Rs 350 or annually Rs. 4,200.

facts.text: Regulation 1 of 1805 made salt manufacture subject to Government control, prohibiting private manufacture.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it is common ground that under the relevant provisions of Regulation 1 of 1805 the manufacture and sale of salt was made subject to the immediate direction and control of the general agent appointed by the Government, and the said manufacture and sale as well as transit, export and import of salt, whether by Bear or by land, in the territory subject to the Presidency of Fort St.- George was prohibited except on account of Government or with their express sanction.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds transaction evidenced by Ex A1 is permanent lease, appellant's claim rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the transaction evidenced by Ex. A. 1 is a permanent lease and that respondent 1 is entitled to retain possession of the whole of the property on the terms and conditions specified in the said document.

The properties came under the possession and control of the Company as a result of the proceedings taken under Regulation 1 of 1805 and the amount of Rs. 4,200/- corresponding to 1848 Pagodas represents the

issues.text: What is the true nature of the relationship between the parties in respect of the properties in suit?

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal the principal question which has been raised before us by Mr. Viswanatha Sastri for the appellant is about the true nature of the relationship between the parties in respect of the properties in suit. He contends that the principal document Ex. A. 1

issues.text: Whether the appellant's claim is barred by limitation under Art. 134 B of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: According to the High Court the appellants claim was also barred by limitation under Art. 134 B  of the Limitation Act. The High Court therefore confirmed the trial courts decree and dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant.

Whether the subsequent conduct of the parties supports the permanent nature of the arrangement.
Whether Ex. A.1 should be construed as executed within the legitimate authority of the temple manager rather than in breach thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Ex A1 shows no duration and prima facie permanent taking; prior correspondence confirms permanent acquisition and fixed compensation on 10-year average; necessity from Regulation 1 of 1805 prohibiting private salt manufacture; presumption of necessity after century lapse per Privy Council; subsequent conduct and quiet enjoyment for 135 years consistent with permanence

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the appellants claim either for possession or for enhancement of rent has been properly rejected by the courts below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule accepted: construe manager's act as within powers rather than ultra vires

holdings.text: where the validity of a permanent lease granted by a shebait comes in question a long time... after the grant... the Court should assume that the grant was made for necessity so as to be valid beyond the life of the grantor... the principle laid down by the Privy Council in that case can well be invoked by respondent 1
holdings.reasoning_summary: Over century elapsed since 1806; presume necessity per Privy Council precedent to validate permanent grant

holdings.text: under the relevant provisions of Regulation 1 of 1805 the manufacture and sale of salt was made subject to the immediate direction and control of the general agent appointed by the Government... prohibited except on account of Government... the manager of the temple was compelled to enter into an arrangement... even the test of the rule of construction... can be said to be satisfied

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulation prohibited private salt manufacture rendering pans useless; created compelling necessity for permanent arrangement

holdings.text: The subsequent conduct of the temple for over a century is consistent with the view that the temple knew that the property has been permanently given to the Company and is inconsistent with the present case that the lease is an annual lease
holdings.reasoning_summary: Quiet enjoyment 1806-1941, uniform rent despite changes, shifting pleas by appellant support permanence
